**Original Post:**
Hello there! I want to be uncaged but currently donâ€™t have the brain power or time to do soâ€¦  (mom of a 3 yo and 9 month twins). Can someone shed some light on the whole â€œyou canâ€™t provide therapy services under cash pay because theyâ€™re billable to Medicareâ€ thing? Do I have that concept wrong? I see people offering â€œwellnessâ€ rather than therapy. 

If the above is how it works, arenâ€™t you by default not providing skilled therapy covered by Medicare if youâ€™re not documenting your services? There is no skill of a therapist if there is no documented skill of a therapist, and no physician signed POC right? What am I missing here or do I have it all wrong? 

Thanks for helping me out if you can. I have a few clients in home health that told me theyâ€™d hire me if I started my own practice, but there is absolutely so much I donâ€™t know and I donâ€™t have the time to figure it all out ğŸ˜… Iâ€™ve just been lurking in here trying to slowly glean information and wrap my head around this concept. Thanks ğŸ˜Š

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Great question Veronica Erlenbush, and letâ€™s get some clarity here. The reason why most PTâ€™s say that you cannot charge cash for Medicare beneficiaries is due to the Meidcare Mandatory Claims Submission Rule. Meaning, if it is skilled PT that Medicare covers, it is mandatory that we submit a claim. Where it gets tricky, is if you have literally no relationship with Medicare, there is no way for you to submit a claim. Here is where it gets confusing: If there is no way to technically submit a claim online, but itâ€™s still mandatory for you to do it as a non-participating providerâ€¦â€¦you can now understand why this is talked about so much lol. Here is where I can give you clarity: Medicare does define wellness as essentially skilled care for the patient. So, if it is unskilled like simple strengthening and endurance, technically that is NOT covered UNLESS a pre-qualifying injury or hospitalization takes place. See where Iâ€™m going here? So, if a Medicare aged client is seeking you out for general strengthening and well-being and they arenâ€™t being treated for a specific injury or disorder, you can have them sign a Medicare beneficiary form decided under their own free will to pay you out-of-pocket for wellness services.

I know itâ€™s a mess. Honestly, Iâ€™m with PTâ€™s who have battled this and called it unconstitutional. They have created a monopoly essentially. 

I believe the only true loophole left, is if they are truly wellness (which the funny thing is thatâ€™s about 90% of HH clients I have seen after they have been discharged from therapy). Then, as long as they are deciding under their own free will because they want to get stronger and pay you, technically they can.

You just have to be okay with some physical therapists saying itâ€™s â€œriskyâ€. I believe Medicare has struck immense levels of fear into our profession to try to make sure they keep their monopoly in place.

But, if a Medicare aged client who doesnâ€™t need skilled therapy comes to me and wants to get stronger to age better, Iâ€™ll see them 10 out of 10 times.

> **Response 2:** As a parent, I'll give you parent version.  You can't take cash from medicare patient for what would be something medicare pays for.  If you a rehabbing a post op knee, can't do it, but if you are keeping them from having pain while playing golf (not a covered service by Medicare) you can.

### Discussion 74: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-06-13 22:24:10 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 30 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/988139065290659/

**Original Post:**
Where does medicare draw the line of 'medically necessary' (I know I'm not the first one to ask this....just frustrated again)?  Say we have someone who can perform their daily functions with no restrictions (but maybe some mild discomfort/pain), however their main complaint is that  they are limited & painful in their ability to go hiking and play pickleball.  Would a wellness plan, with a treatment focus around making hiking & pickleball easier for them to participate in,  even if it entailed some manual therapy skills, be allowed under a cash-pay arrangement?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Donâ€™t confuse services covered under the Medicare benefit with medical necessity. 

Medical necessity is just one part of the requirements for covered services. 

Reasonable is another part. 

Standard of care is another part. 

This is a balancing act for sure. As Nancy mentioned, you are the therapist and make your determination based on the initial evaluation and findings. 

After that you develop your treatment plan and based on published guidelines you make a determination of what YOU believe falls within the coverage guidelines. 

You may charge cash for non-covered services and seek reimbursement for covered services. 

But reimbursement is always conditional. 

Ultimately you are not the one paying the bill nor is your patient. So Medicare would make the final determination if it ever came to that under review. 

And when Medicare makes that determination the Medicare rep will look at published guidelines and your documentation. 

I would say by far most of what I see in small, private practice outpatient therapy is largely non-covered services. But therapists are so desperate to help their patients they are willing to assume the financial liability associated with over utilization of services. Or they just donâ€™t understand the intent of Medicare coverage.

> **Response 2:** Sounds a lot more like a cash pay service. Unfortunately Medicare isnâ€™t concerned about someoneâ€™s ability to play pickle ballâ€¦ regardless of how important it is to the client

**Original Post:**
I need help! I was seeing a patient with Luna (outpatient at home) and patient was in the process of having Luna become an official provider with her Mass Mutual long term care insurance. She was not using Medicare whatsoever. She was self pay with Luna and Mass Mutual after 90 days would begin to reimburse her. Long story short, the patient and her husband became so irritated with the process (Luna and MM) that they have decided to hire me (cash based) to see her. 

If they do clear me as a provider, I am wanting to make sure 1. Mass Mutual understands that I am mobile outpatient and not home health. 2. If she was paying Luna self pay at $125, is it totally off to pay me cash?

After 90 days of care (she started with home health then moved on to outpatient) they will reimburse her services once they get the invoice. I left the clinic to not have to deal with insurance. Iâ€™m venting and asking for opinions on this, whether I should take her or not. She would pay me and I would provide an invoice just like Luna would have done for her. 

Hope this makes sense! Thoughts?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Besides the Medicare issue, I had a similar patient who wanted me to work with her when I wasnâ€™t established. I gave her receipts. But then she wanted to submit all the receipts to her long-term care and get reimbursed. The long-term care insurance wanted full codes, and Proof of billing that Medicare rejected it before paying for it. I would just make sure that sheâ€™s not using your bills to get paid back because then it opens up a can of worms. ï¿¼

> **Response 2:** Tricky situation. Typically the purpose of a LTC plan is to cover costs for the insured if they lose the ability or need significant help with at least 2 of 6 functional tasks: bathing, eating, dressing, toileting, bed transfers, and chair transfers. If her home health discharge OASIS paperwork showed that she was independent with these, Mass Mutual may have a case not to pay them. You would essentially have to show that she is restricted with at least 2 of these.

Since she still has Medicare, there still may be a case from a CMS federal level that she canâ€™t pay you cash if you/the patient are trying to  make a case that her treatment is medically necessary (because she has functional limitations that need treatment) 

I personally wouldnâ€™t take them as cash pay and would have them continue to go through Luna and/or use Medicare part B insurance. If she needs services like dry needling or other skills that are helpful and not covered by Medicare, I would invoice them for that and they can submit those services to Mass Mutual. They may still be eligible for some reimbursement and you wouldnâ€™t be caught in a battle between CMS and their private LTC policy

> **Response 1:** They should have read the book they're given each year to explain how their health services are billed. ğŸ˜‘  If in person, ask to see their cards first. If not, have them email a copy. You need that to verify coverage anyway. Tell them up front you don't take Medicare Advantage plans. If they are not paying anything extra each month than their $174.90 that is usually subtracted from their Social Security payments, they probably have an Advantage plan. Although some Advantage plans have extra premiums as well. Sounds like their Insurance agent didn't educate them well. It's the job of the agent to make sure they understand their coverage. I would direct them back to their agent if you don't want to spend the time. 

Traditional Medicare is quite costly. I remember my mom paying up to $454 a month over her base premium (now $174.90). And she wasn't really ill until her last year alive. Only hospitalized for 2 TIAs and having 3 children. You are going to see more and more taking Advantage plans. They have a max out of pocket limit that lowers the financial risk. If you are not an ill person, Advantage plans make sense. Plus you get dental and vision benefits, and other perks. Otherwise you are paying close to $600 a month for Insurance you may or may not use

If they have Advantage I explain they chose to give up their Medicare benefits to an insurance company who now â€œmanagesâ€ their health care like any other insurance company. > **Response 2:** Its the basis of how medicare works and advantage plans follow the guildelines they just "manage" it a lot more. Medicare A/"advantage" A allows for up to 100 days of consecutive services (typically paid at days 1-20 100%, then often 80% after. **Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Hi. Crucial clarification here: Is the Aetna plan a supplemental? (I think it'll say so on their insurance card.)

You only ever need to be in network with the primary payer -- the primary payer will automatically send the remainder of the (approved) bill to the supplemental. You'll get a check in the mail from the supplemental later; timing varies. 

If the Aetna plan is their primary plan, then it's a Medicare replacement. Don't bother going in network with those, generally speaking, unless you have really good reasons. If their plan has OON benefits for PT, they reimburse at the same rates as Medicare would have. 

Please feel free to set up a call with me if you need more guidance -- since we've chatted about some of these things already.

Thanks so much!
Edited to add: they already use medicare services but want extra hours of cash PT each week outside of their medicare services

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** You must bill Medicare for medically necessary skilled therapy services. Clients are not allowed to pay cash for these services. If they are received wellness services (be clear on how you define this) that are not covered by Medicare then there is no form that they need to sign.  If the services might normally be covered but do not meet the skilled therapy medically necessary code outlined in Section 220.2 of CMS Chapter 15 then  you will need to have the client sign an ABN. Here is the link to Chapter 15 https://www.cms.gov/Regulations-and-Guidance/Guidance/Manuals/downloads/bp102c15.pdf   Here is a link on how to correctly complete an ABN. https://www.cms.gov/Medicare/Medicare-General-Information/BNI/Downloads/ABN-Form-Instructions.pdf

### Discussion 273: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-11-13 18:00:33 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 11 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1897618074342749/

**Original Post:**
If someone is using the VA for the home health, can we see them for Medicare part B?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Are they admitted to VA Home Based Primary Care Program?  The team included PT.  Seems to be some confusion about receiving HBPC PT at the same time skilled home heath PT or Part B outpatient PT is used. The HBPC PT performs annual assessment at minimum and supports with additional visits for equipment assessment and trial, follow up training, HEP instruction, follow up assessment after hospitalization, maintenance intervention.  
So if the client is receiving HBPC, they may have Part B OR Part A PT services. 
VA is providing HHOT and HHST - for example in our catchment area, HHOT follows Part B documentation/billing and HHST follows Part A/skilled HH billing. 
All VA's are not the same due to location, availability of services etc.

> **Response 2:** It would be important to clarify if the veteran is referring to Home Based Primary Care (a VA service for homebound veterans that includes a NP, RN, SW, Dietician, Pharmacist, Psychologist, and rehab therapist: PT/OT). That is just primary care but in the home and veterans can still use Medicare Part B while enrolled in HBPC assuming they have Medicare Part B. Otherwise, home health is home health whether they are a veteran or not, and you would not be paid through Part B

### Discussion 295: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-06-18 17:50:22 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 10 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1493298298108064/

**Original Post:**
Had a client submit a superbill for out of network coverage through Cigna. Was told Dx code M54.5 LBP â€œis out of date or invalidâ€ - any thoughts as to why? Thanks

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** The diagnosis code M54.5 for low back pain (LBP) is considered out of date or invalid because it was replaced by a more specific code in the ICD-10-CM (International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision, Clinical Modification) updates. As of October 1, 2021, the code M54.5 has been replaced with the following more specific codes:

- M54.50: Low back pain, unspecified
- M54.51: Vertebrogenic low back pain
- M54.59: Other low back pain

Cigna and other insurance companies require the use of the most current ICD-10-CM codes for claims processing. You will need to update the superbill with the appropriate new code for low back pain to ensure it is accepted. 

To determine the correct code:
- If the low back pain is unspecified, use **M54.50**.
- If the low back pain is vertebrogenic, use **M54.51**.
- For other specified types of low back pain, use **M54.59**.

> **Response 2:** In my previous employment (insurance based system) we were notified low back pain M54.50 usually wasnâ€™t covered by insurances. Usually had to be more specific like radiculopathy (M54.16) or vertebrogenic (M54.51). But not sure how super billing reimbursement looks for it! Good luck with it!

Hi all! I was speaking to a local chiropractor (I am a physical therapist looking to launch my own business) she was telling meâ€¦

â€œshe believes as a licensed healthcare provider you will need to register with CMS/Medicare in order to treat any patients.  That you can register as a Non-par provider and should be allowed to accept cash from a Medicare patients. Charges must â€œbe in alignment with customary & reasonable for your regionâ€.  I guess this has something to do with discrimination practices.  But I guess thatâ€™s the Medicare handcuffs, because Medicare patients are allowed to request reimbursement from Medicare and/or deduct medical expenses from their taxes which they are required to receive legit services from licensed practitioners blah, blah.  So bottom line, whether or not you bill/charge/submit to Medicare or not, you have to register with them as a non-par provider.â€ 

From what I can tell for physical therapist, the only way I could see a Medicare patient for cash if itâ€™s truly a â€œwellnessâ€ session. But do I need to register as this â€œnon-par providerâ€? I am in Illinois if that makes a difference!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Hi, Katherine Reinertson Wood thanks for asking this. I've been a Medicare provider (PT) for over 5 years, and this local chiropractor is a bit off base! Sounds like she is trying to explain to you what a Non-par provider is. Basically, you need to enroll with Medicare if you want to treat Medicare patients and submit claims. You can enroll as either participating or non-participating provider (confusing, right??!) Non-par does not mean you have no relationship with Medicare, you cannot accept cash (self-pay) from a Medicare patient as a Non-par provider. I would recommend checking out Tony Anthony Maritatos Facebook Group Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group. > **Response 2:** There are 3 categories:
- affiliated with Medicare, Participating
- affiliated with Medicare, non-Participating
- no affiliation

If you are not affiliated you cannot treat anything that would be reimbursable under Medicare for PT. Non-medically necessary items (such as wellness), can be cash billed.

**Original Post:**
I am a solo practitioner practice currently utilizing a cash-pay model. The goal is to grow to multiple therapists and have multiple revenue streams with a 24/7 gym space and other holistic wellness offerings in the future. I do not want to go away from a largely based cash model because the liberty to actually practice our craft with fewer limitations has been amazing, but have recently felt a pull to contracting with Medicare and Medicaid to serve patients who may not be able to afford our services otherwise. My question is, how tricky does it get when people have secondary coverage in addition to their Medicare or have Medicare replacement plans, as I would not be contracting with secondary or Medicare replacement insurance plans?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Secondary coverage (medigap plansO) are automatic and we don't individually credential with those to be paid. 

With being OON with MedAdvantage plans keep in mind that if the plan has OON benefits, and you submit a claim, you are limited to charging Medicare allowables. To truly keep things cash pay you cannot ever submit those claims, just continue with the route of cash pay + superbills. 

Also keep in mind that if you ever credential in the future, that standard commercial (such as RegenceBCBS) and MedAdv commercial (such as MedAdv RegenceBCBS) are typically credentialed together as they're administered by the same company.

> **Response 2:** Just communicate up front that you are not taking Medicare Advantage plans. They are ridiculous and I got screwed over several times, finally learned my lesson and started having the hard conversations. But, nearly 50% of those over 65 apparently have opted for those plans, so they would have to shift back to traditional Medicare then to access your services.

### Discussion 382: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT]

**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1220237942080769/

**Original Post:**
Has anyone decided to go with an HSA tied to a mutual fund with catastrophic care coverage vs. standard insurance for themselves and their employees?  Thinking pros vs. cons on something like this.  To be honest Iâ€™ve heard this could be a fiscally smart long term option but I donâ€™t even know where to begin.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Have maxed out contributions to a HSA for years. Significant tax advantages (pre-tax contributions, tax free withdrawal, tax free capital gains -- all assuming these fund qualified medical expenses). I also leave it fully invested in S&P500 Index Funds (as opposed to higher cost mutual funds) and covered put options on S&P500 ETFs. It's about as hands off as it gets for passive management while avoiding ridiculous fees. One could argue (myself included) that a ROTH IRA should be fully funded prior to an HSA. Important to remember that if one can afford to pay for medical expenses currently out of pocket that you can "reimburse" yourself at any point down the road!

> **Response 2:** Max out both roth and hsa if possible. Tax advantages are huge for later in life. If you are nervous about a catastrophic medical bill, you can always keep the equivalent of your deductible in the hsa non-invested. The math in most scenarios usually favors the hsa plan vs a quality plan IF you contribute to the hsa account.

**Original Post:**
Hello everyone,
Iâ€™m a new practice owner and have a quick question. A patient recently contacted me after being involved in a car accident. Pt has a claim number from her auto insurance, which is already using for chiropractic care, and now she would like to start physical therapy with me. Pt  plans to submit the claims to her auto insurance.

For those of you with experience in these situations, how do you typically handle such cases? Any guidance or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Whoever submits first, gets paid first. If you end up seeing them on a lien, then you won't get paid until it is settled. That can take time....I've seen it take a few months to years for payment to be distributed. You'll want to have a contract with the attorney in place. fyi...some attorneys will come back at a later date and try to negotiate payment to a lower amount.

> **Response 2:** Call the auto insurance, speak to the person handling your patients case. Find out if the PIP policy (personal injury policy) is exhausted or if thereâ€™s still money in it. Typically it is $10,000 and they pay out claims as they come in. So what Heidi Grove Harmon said is correct. Submit your billing immediately. 
They will not tell you how much is left in the policy, so have your patient call and find out. Once that money is gone, if you choose to continue treating them, it will be on a lien with the lawyer so you will have to contact themï¿¼

**Original Post:**
I am a LMT and CLT. I provide lipedema care. I do not accept insurance; I'm cash based. A client is trying to get her insurance to reimburse her for my services. I received a letter from BCBS saying that I am not on file with them and they provided a link to their credentialing page. As a LMT, I'm not familiar with what this means. Do I need to go through the process so the cleint can be reimbursed? I have zero intention of billing insurance directly.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Many insurances require you to be "credentialed" in order for the be willing to accept any documentation from you, whether it be a super bill or CMS 1500.

Credentialing is not usually the same thing as "contracted" or in-network.  With credentialing, the usually want a W-9 and your information to simply list you in their system.  No contract needed.

They might not accept the superbill if they require you to be credentialed.

> **Response 2:** It is possible to be Credentialed as an OON provider. If you complete any credentialing, then you want to ensure that you are not being asked to enter into a contract with them and their contracted rate. More often than not, an insurance can process the superbill provided to the patient with a copy if your W-9 to verify your business information.

Hello all! Does anyone have experience working with someone who has BCBS primary, and Medicare secondary? I am mobile and primarily OON/cash pay, but am participating in Medicare Part B. This is a process I'm finding online, and looking for clarification and confirmation of understanding.

From what I'm seeing, I would try to submit the claim to BCBS (or have the patient submit the claim?) for OON benefits. BCBS would likely pay nothing, and then send back an EOB stating as much. This EOB could then be submitted to Medicare, for usual reimbursement (0% until deductible, 80% after). The patient would then be responsible for the remainder (20%). 

Does this sound accurate? Or are there other components I need to be aware of?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Med part b will pay 80% and then bcbs will do the 20%. 

I'm non-par and all of the claims I've submitted this far have been automatically forwarded to the secondary.

My experience is that bcbs will only issue the payment to the patient for OON claims.  For that reason,  we keep a card on file so that way once the claim processes and if bcbs has paid the patient we can still get paid. All of our patients have sent the money directly to us,  but I know that some therapists have had to eat the cost of the 20% because the patient refused to send the money that bcbs sent them.

> **Response 2:** I used to do billing, yes that sounds about right. 

Sometimes the payment and EOB goes to patient so make sure you have in written form and signed by patient that it is their responsibility to provide that to you, or they would be liable.

**Original Post:**
Hey guys! I'm in the process of getting my cash-based mobile PT business started and am trying to figure out the legality of treating clients as cash pay who have Medicare as their primary insurance. I've read from numerous sources that it is illegal to treat as cash pay when they could potentially get Medicare to cover their services, even if the services we provide are medically necessary. I've also seen or heard of others who do accept clients with Medicare insurance, but inform them that they will not get reimbursed and/or put in writing something along the lines of the clients declining to receive PT services under their Medicare insurance. Is there some way to word on intake forms that would allow cash pay businesses to see Medicare clients or is it illegal in every way?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Unfortunately PT cannot opt out of Medicare, so if it is a medically necessary covered service by Medicare, you cannot charge cash for it. If it is something not covered by Medicare, you can charge cash for it. That is why a lot of us have a â€œwellnessâ€ component to our businesses, to offer more than is covered by Medicare. This can include, any service provided outside of the home (gym, park, grocery store), needing help cleaning up their home, HEP compliance when PT is no longer necessary, coaching/training, etc. Chapter 15 of CMS is a great resource to start diving into.

> **Response 2:** PTs cannot legally opt out of Medicare. 
Any medically necessary service requires a Medicare claim to be filed.

### Discussion 719: 

**Date:** 2024-09-28 21:01:18 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 4 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1564119864359240/

**Original Post:**
I am hearing of multiple mobile PTs in my area that are having clients sign a waiver that basically states the clients are not going to bill Medicare for their services/are giving up their Medicare rights to get around the mandated Medicare rule for PT. They are having patients sign this and then charging cash. Thoughts on this? 
I thought this was sketchy but then found multiple people are doing it, so I was curious what the group thought.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Answer from chat GPT: No, a physical therapist cannot have a patient on Medicare sign a waiver to bypass Medicare and charge cash for covered services. Medicare has strict rules about billing, and providers must bill Medicare for services that are covered unless they have opted out of Medicare.

If a service is covered by Medicare, providers must submit a claim to Medicare, and patients cannot be asked to pay out-of-pocket for that service. There are some exceptions for non-covered services, but for covered services, bypassing Medicare is not allowed.

In rare cases, a physical therapist who has officially opted out of Medicare may have private agreements with patients, but this requires specific formalities.

> **Response 2:** I know multiple outpatient clinics (privately owned) in my area that make patients sign ABNs thus giving up their Medicare rights and also avoiding the clinic from being audited. They have some patients on caseload for 3+ years.

They probably will never be investigated by Medicare. Do I agree itâ€™s wrong 100%. But people do what you are saying 100%.

**Original Post:**
Hello My Fellow Colleagues,

Is anyone out there seeing Medicare beneficiaries for wellness, fitness, prevention (WFP) for CASH? Anthony Maritato has some great YT vids on this, but I'm still looking for clarity.

1. I understand Medicare will cover maintenance if skilled care. Otherwise, are all WFP needs automatically defaulted as non-skilled and would never be covered by Medicare?
If non-covered, what's the point of an ABN? Other than purely a voluntary ABN to cover you maybe ?

2. Client wants help establishing a year long plan but wants/needs assessment. What's unclear to me is...let's say they have mobility issues, no pain. How do I assess shoulder dysfunction outside of a skilled care lens? Aren't I, as a DPT, examining shoulder mobility...as a DPT?? How do I know what will suit them best for a year long program and more if I don't eval and examine them (which, arguably, feels like a skilled function)?

3. Lastly, are there any restrictions/limitations on what I can charge for non-covered Medicare services since they still technically have power and authority over us and I'm not allowed to opt-out of their program like every other practitioner can?

Thank you for ANY info. 

Signed,
-Tried to get out of the cage, cage keeps dragging me back in.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I have several cash-pay clients that have been to and don't want any further "therapy."  They want a highly skilled personal trainer who can program and progress exercises for general strength, balance, etc in the presence of their chronic conditions.  They have confidence in me because of my medical background.
I also started a group fitness class for 55+, so am reaching more people and helping them reach their fitness/function goals with an evidence-based program.

> **Response 2:** 1:  ABN not required for wellness services/non-covered services.
2:  You can bill eval to determine if there are further skilled needs or not.
3:  No restrictions on what you charge for non-covered services.  If you are not providing a skilled service, then Medicare does not have "power and authority" over you.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I do OON billing when:
They have OON benefits with low deductible (<$2500 - arbitrary based on typical POC for my patients) or have already met their deductible AND high reimbursement rates (UCR based fee schedule)
I give a Superbill to people who have OON benefits with high deductible (>$2500) or low reimbursement rate (Medicare percentage based or their own that is lower than UCR rates).

> **Response 2:** Factor the OON billing into your rates. If you are set up with a clearinghouse, OON billing is pretty simple.

### Discussion 771: 

**Date:** 2025-06-13 13:30:52 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 3 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1764380287666529/

**Original Post:**
Good morning and happy Friday the 13th groupğŸ˜±ğŸ˜³. Someone might have posted this question before but I have a former patient that reached out to me that I was seeing through another company I contracted for via her insurance (Medicare). She recently reached out to me and stated that she has been having issues with another problem, that doesnâ€™t require surgery but her physician want her to go to PT. She reached out to my business and wanted me to help her with a training program that could help her but she wants to pay cash. Medicare confuses me, is this a ğŸ‘ğŸ¿ or ğŸ‘ğŸ¿, thanks

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** The simple guideline is you can't take cash from some one with Medicare for medically necessary services, other than the 20% co-insurance patient responsibility (assuming they don't have a secondary) or their deductible if it's unpaid. 

If you've done an evaluation and determined that services are not medically necessary/don't require the skills of a PT, then you can create and charge for a wellness program. 

PT's cannot opt out of Medicare like medical providers can.

Document the heck out of it and assess your own risk tolerance. 

According to a number of individuals, there are very specific methods to try to work around this for medically necessary services. If you're asking this question here, and have not set yourself up with good legal advice for those ways, you don't want to consider them.

### Discussion 808: 

**Date:** 2025-06-12 15:11:51 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 3 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1763603867744171/

**Original Post:**
Would love some knowledge and expertise on this as Iâ€™ve been scratching my head thinking about this the last few weeks!

I am new to the cash based physical therapy game as well as just simply billing insurances as I worked full time as a home health PT-all the billing, etc was handled by the company I worked for.

I am currently starting a cash based practice and I know we provide superbills for patients. I have written that we do not bill insurance directly but will provide superbills if needed to submit to insurance companies for possible reimbursements and to contact said insurance companies prior to starting with me for information on whatâ€™s covered. 

Should I offer cash based services and get in net work with some major insurance companies or just provide superbills? Iâ€™m confused because I feel if I accept some insurances it may make it a lighter financial burden. 

Can someone expalin the pros and cons of superbills vs getting in network with certain insurances  or even how to start that process. 

A little lost ğŸ¤

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** It depends on what you want to do..

Insurance based practices don't have a shortage of patients and people will go to see an insurance based provider regardless of their skills simply because they are in network...and I get it because premiums are expensive so people want to use their insurance. As a provider accepting insurance you do have to play by insurances rules (authorizations, documentation requests, reimbursement limits, co-pay and/or co-insurance collection, etc)

For cash based you can give a superbill and move on. It may take longer to build your clientele simply because some people want to use their insurance. You have the flexibility of setting your rate and determining the need for treatment without insurance influence.  You also don't have the same administrative requirements for billing submission, authorizations, etc. 

Insurance reimbursement is generally less than cash based; however, depending on your market and target audience it may make sense for your business model. 

I personally am non-par with Medicare and limit the number of Medicare patients ai have on my caseload at one time. Otherwise, I am completely cash based. I used to run a busy outpatient clinic that accepted most major insurances and some of those insurances were an absolute pain to work with. Others, weren't bad. Still, you have to run the numbers and see what works for your business model.

Also, I think it is important to understand that not allow services or physical therapy needs are truly covered by insurance and that in these situations, cash based is acceptable.

> **Response 2:** You can only offer cash to a Medicare recipient if it is wellness or a non-covered service. Physical therapists cannot opt out of Medicare

### Discussion 845: 

**Date:** 2023-06-09 19:00:32 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 3 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1258533348251228/

**Original Post:**
Trying to understand simple logistics.

 If you're an OON provider- do you come up with your price (ie for eval). If the patient agrees, they pay you the eval price up front (ie: $100). 
After treatment, you provide a superbill which the patient provides to his/her insurance. Depending on their plan coverage the insurance company then reimburses them. This could be nothing or what ever we charged via super bill?

Also, the superbill amount can be more or less than what you charged the patient (ie: $100)? 

Next as an OON provider- credentialing you or your business isn't needed?

 Also checks of benefits? Do any of you guys do that or leave it up to your patients?

Lastly, what kind of notes do you keep on hand as an OON? Similar to those as in network?

Thanks for reading and answering my questions. Trying to understand the game a lil better ğŸ¤£

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** the superbill can not be more than you charged the patient.  if they had reached their out of pocket max, the insurance company would refund all of it. (as long as charges are reasonable and customary)  charging more on your superbill than what u charged thebpatient, esp. in this scenario,  would constitute insurance fraud.  second point, documentarion is a state board requirement.  whether u are in or OON.(assuming care is skilled)..board requirementsdo not change for skilled care

> **Response 2:** I have my rates for all CPTs codes. So for an eval I charge $250 and the patient pays that at the time of service. I provide a superbill with the code, rate, what the patient paid. Then patient submits that to their insurance. If they have an OON Deductible it will get applied to that. Once that is met the insurance will reimburse them based on their fee schedule. 

Letâ€™s say the insurance fee schedule for 97163 is $150. Each visit only $150 is applied to the deductible (even though the patient is paying me $250). Once met the patient has a 30% coinsurance. Insurance will reimburse the patient 70% of $150, so the total cost for the patient is 30% of $150 PLUS the $100 difference between the fee schedules. As the ONN provider is doesnâ€™t matter because they already paid you $250. They should expect to only be reimbursed $105 (70% of $150) once deductible is met.

I have the patient contact their insurance to ask about their ONN benefits. I tried to do it and they would always give me the wrong info so I stopped.

If you tell patients you will give them a superbill for possible reimbursement you should make sure your documentation is detailed enough for insurances. Because they may require the patient to submit documentation. Also some plans require you to get prior auth even as OON. You donâ€™t have to but then the patient wonâ€™t be reimbursed. Again I have the patient find all of that out first. 

I will also give the patient a W9 form to submit with the superbill if Iâ€™ve never had a patient with their insurance in the past.

Is it true that you cannot treat Medicare patients on a cash pased basis? Does anyone know how to get around this if so?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** PTs cannot opt out of medicare so you can't charge a person with medicare cash for a service that medicare would cover. You can, with some stipulations, if they have a managed medicare plan as primary.
